Group Details.Description: Naikonis assessed to be a state-sponsored cyber espionage group attributed to the Chinese People’s Liberation Army’s (PLA) Chengdu Military Region Second Technical Reconnaissance Bureau (Military Unit Cover Designator 78020).[1]Active since at least 2010,Naikonhas primarily conducted operations against government, military, and civil organizations in Southeast Asia, as well as against international bodies such as the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).[1][2]WhileNaikonshares some characteristics withAPT30, the two groups do not appear to be exact matches.[3]

Associated Groups.Name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
Associated Groups.Use: Naikon has modified a victim's Windows Run registry to establish persistence.[4]

Associated Groups.Name: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Side-Loading
Associated Groups.Use: Naikon has used DLL side-loading to load malicious DLL's into legitimate executables.[5]

Associated Groups.Name: Masquerading: Masquerade Task or Service
Associated Groups.Use: Naikon renamed a malicious service taskmgr to appear to be a legitimate version of Task Manager.[4]

Associated Groups.Name: Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location
Associated Groups.Use: Naikon has disguised malicious programs as Google Chrome, Adobe, and VMware executables.[4]

Associated Groups.Name: Network Service Discovery
Associated Groups.Use: Naikon has used the LadonGo scanner to scan target networks.[4]

Associated Groups.Name: Office Application Startup: Add-ins
Associated Groups.Use: Naikon has used the RoyalRoad exploit builder to drop a second stage loader, intel.wll, into the Word Startup folder on the compromised host.[5]

Associated Groups.Name: Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment
Associated Groups.Use: Naikon has used malicious e-mail attachments to deliver malware.[5]

Associated Groups.Name: Remote System Discovery
Associated Groups.Use: Naikon has used a netbios scanner for remote machine identification.[4]

Associated Groups.Name: Scheduled Task/Job: Scheduled Task
Associated Groups.Use: Naikon has used schtasks.exe for lateral movement in compromised networks.[4]

Associated Groups.Name: Software Discovery: Security Software Discovery
Associated Groups.Use: Naikon uses commands such as netsh advfirewall firewall to discover local firewall settings.[2]

Associated Groups.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Associated Groups.Use: Naikon uses commands such as netsh interface show to discover network interface settings.[2]

Associated Groups.Name: User Execution: Malicious File
Associated Groups.Use: Naikon has convinced victims to open malicious attachments to execute malware.[5]

Associated Groups.Name: Valid Accounts: Domain Accounts
Associated Groups.Use: Naikon has used administrator credentials for lateral movement in compromised networks.[4]

Associated Groups.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Associated Groups.Use: Naikon has used WMIC.exe for lateral movement.[4]
